Patch Question: Arby's in Bellmore
Sound off on the daily hot topic.
THE NEIGHBORHOOD FILES Danielle De Souza Tuesday, October 25, 2011
Arby's opened in Bellmore a few weeks ago after much debate and concern. Residents who live near the franchise were concerned with traffic, late drive-thru hours, noise, early morning food deliveries and more. But, after many meetings and discussions, the owner and the community were able to come to agreements on how the eatery would be run. How do you feel about Arby's opening in Bellmore? Do you live near the restaurant? If so, do you feel it is a disturbance to you and your family? Do you think it would be good for the community? Or are you not concerned about it at all? Tell us in the comment section below.

Fast food chain is first of its kind for Bellmore.
THE NEIGHBORHOOD FILES Danielle De Souza Tuesday, October 25, 2011
After a series of community meetings and concessions, Arby's opened on Sunrise Highway about two weeks ago. The main civic group involved said they came to agreements that they felt were beneficial to both the community and the eatery. Matthew Walden of the Bellmore Preservation Group said that Arby's owner, Thomas J. Clarke, his lawyer, William Bonesso, his architect and members of the community all worked together."The Arby's really worked with the community,"Walden said. Bonesso said that after many discussions, Arby's made some changes to the original plans for the franchise:"I think that it was a satisfactory agreement that the community and the owner came up with,"Bonesso said. Zoning Board Sets Conditions for Arby's Application Approval
Fast food franchise granted several variances that are subject to several conditions set by the Hempstead Town BZA.
GOVERNMENT Jaime Sumersille Thursday, August 19, 2010
The Hempstead Town Zoning Board granted the Arby's application subject to the following conditions: 1. The door situated on the rear (south side) of the Arby's building shall not be used for deliveries of any kind. 2. No deliveries to the subject premises shall occur before 7 a.m. 3. The hours of operation for the restaurant and drive-thru shall be as follows: Restaurant: 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. Drive-thru: Sunday though Wednesday – 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. Thursday through Saturday – 6 a.m. to midnight; 4. The premises shall be landscaped and professionally irrigated in accordance with the landscaping depicted on the site plan prepared by Rosenbaum Design Group, originally dated Sept. 25, 2009, last revised Jan. 20, 2010. Franchise owner agrees to almost all conditions requested by neighbors.
GOVERNMENT Jaime Sumersille Wednesday, July 28, 2010
Attorneys for an Arby's franchise owner finally made their case before the Hempstead Town Zoning Board Wednesday afternoon after three adjournments. Bellmore Preservation Group Reviews Arby's Application
Residents discuss site plan changes for fast food restaurant proposal with franchise owner.
BUSINESS Jaime Sumersille Wednesday, June 30, 2010
An Arby's franchise owner, his architect and lawyer met with the Bellmore Preservation Group last night to discuss the fast food restaurant's proposed building plans. The proposed 3,900 sq. ft. building would be located just east of Sunrise Highway and Bellmore Avenue. It would be two stories high, with 17' being the tallest height, have seating for 66 people and 27 parking spots. The applicant, Thomas J. Clarke, his attorney William F. Bonesso, Esq. and architect Dennis Flynn of Rosebaum Design Group addressed every single concern raised by residents in previous meetings. UPDATED: Bellmore White Castle Rejected
Zoning board ruling a victory for families who fought the fast food restaurant.
GOVERNMENT Jaime Sumersille Thursday, June 3, 2010
Nearly 2.5 months after a Town of Hempstead Zoning hearing, hundreds of Bellmore residents finally got the answer they had been waiting and fighting for. There will be no White Castle. The board unanimously denied the application, said Susan Trenkle-Pokalsky, Hempstead's press secretary."As a community, we are ecstatic,"said Matt Walden, a member of the Bellmore Preservation Group."The community came together. Everybody worked together and had their voices heard."The group is made up of about 100 families who scraped together nearly $12,000 for legal fees and other costs to fight - and ultimately defeat - the White Castle.
